me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder2.math

Interface Spline

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    LinearSpline, MonotoneCubicSpline, ZeroSlopeSpline

    public interface Spline
    A spline. I don't know much of a better way to explain it, to be entirely honest. Maybe just Google it? Good luck. As some potentially more useful documentation, a spline is basically a gay line. Or a curvy line. I like boys, I'm allowed to say that. Anyways. You provide a set of control points and in turn you get an object you can use to calculate positions according to the spline.

    For general purposes, you should use MonotoneCubicSpline.

    Splines are generally most useful for high-performance trajectories. Although classic linear trajectories are incredibly cool, splines are even cooler, especially because they allow you to cut some corners (quite literally) with movement, meaning you have to traverse less distance.

    Splines must be created with points that have either strictly increasing or strictly decreasing X values. For some examples... This would be VALID.

    • x = 10, y = 10
    • x = 20, y = 10
    • x = 30, y = 10
    This would be VALID.
    • x = 30, y = 10
    • x = 20, y = 10
    • x = 10, y = 10
    This would be INVALID.
    • x = 20, y = 10
    • x = 30, y = 10
    • x = 10, y = 10
    As you can see, the X values simply have to go in the same direction.

    Since:
    0.0.0
    Author:
    Colin Robertson

      • interpolateY

        double interpolateY(double x)
        Interpolate a Y value from an X value.
        Parameters:
        x - the current X value.
        Returns:
        the interpolated Y value.

      • interpolate

        PointXY interpolate(double x)
        Interpolate a PointXY from an X value. This should return a point created with an X value equal to the provided X value and a Y value found using interpolateY(double).
        Parameters:
        x - the current X value.
        Returns:
        the interpolated point.
